awd_titl_txt: CAS: Developing Methods for Reaction Modeling to Tune Catalysts for Substrate Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Aaron Odom of the Department of Chemistry at Michigan State University to develop a model to predict catalyst efficiency. The catalysts that Professor Odom and his research group are studying are complexes of titanium and vanadium, which are early transition metals that are earth abundant and offer unique chemical products. This more sustainable reactivity model will minimize the time and effort required for the optimization of catalytic systems that are commonly used in industry. While similar studies have been performed for late transition metal catalysts that are used for different types of applications, this model has been designed for early transition metal catalysts. These studies are advancing an initial model previously developed by Professor Odom to be able to function with a larger number of reaction variables and different types of catalyst-substrate interactions. The program is also discovering new ways to adapt the model to catalysts that are attached to solid supports. A diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students are being trained through their participation in these activities and a chemical demonstration team is being organized to engage local K-12 students in STEM disciplines.

Ligand parametrization methods have recently been established as valuable tools for catalyst optimization with late transition metal systems. Although early transition metal catalysts are used in a variety of industrial processes for the conversion of petrochemical products to value-added commodities, catalytic performance predictive methods have been slower to evolve in this area. The Odom laboratory has developed the first model to systematize the factors that control the reactivity of titanium-catalysts used for hydroamination. These researchers are now advancing their working model to be able to handle new challenges such as non-symmetrical ligand systems and multicomponent reactions.  In addition, the method is being designed to accommodate silica-supported titanium catalysts and vanadium olefin isomerization catalysts that require consideration of new types of catalyst-substrate interactions. These studies are providing training for graduate and undergraduate students in the field of inorganic/organometallic chemistry and chemical experimentation as well as in machine learning with applications to artificial intelligence in molecular design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Catalysis is estimated to contribute to about 30% of the U.S. G.D.P., with much of that coming through petroleum refining, polymers production, and contributions to pharmaceutical production. While modeling of late transition metal catalysts has been studied extensively for decades, we are developing methods for modeling early transition metal systems, which are also used in fine and bulk chemical synthesis but have seen far less systematic development of modeling approaches. For this, we have invented a new method for measuring how ligands affect the electronic structure of metal centers they are attached to, simply called the Ligand Donor Parameter (LDP). This can be combined with a method of evaluating the size of the ligand to understand how ligands on the metal combine to give the reactivity observed.

In order to have LDP values of sufficient accuracy to be useful, we developed an experimental method for determination of the donor ability of the ligand of interest (X). The system used is NCr(NiPr2)2X, where the X ligand competes with diisopropylamide p-donation. The donor property of X is then related to the rotation rate of the amide ligand, which is determined by spin-saturation transfer in the 1H NMR. Using the Eyring and Gibbs equations, and assuming a constant entropy for different X ligands influencing amide rotation, one can calculate the enthalpic barrier for amide rotation, which is used as LDP. This allows us to build up charts of ligand donor ability (Fig. 1). 

Whereas the X ligands in LDP are generally anionic in previous work; as part of this project we investigated the related system NV(NH2)2L computationally, where L is a neutral, 2-electron donor such as phosphines. It was found that ligand effects in these high oxidation state systems are, in some cases, quite different from what is found in low oxidation state systems. For example, phosphites were found to be much better donors than expected due to negative hyperconjugation effects, and these findings may influence how others use such ligands in catalysis.

We were able to publish the first example of a simple modeling of an early transition metal system (Fig 2), which included a diverse array of ancillary ligand structures. (Only one catalyst is shown in Fig 2, but each point is a different catalyst with a somewhat different structure.) The mathematical model clearly shows how one can improve the catalysis by using the ligand parameters to translate the structure to a mathematical constant that can be used to understand the rate. In ongoing work, we are looking at more sophisticated models of the same catalytic reaction to get an even deeper understanding of how structure affects rate, and we are expanding the use of the method to other catalytic reactions. These new modeling methods are being used in our group to improve methods for the use of Earth abundant titanium to make pharmacologically-active heterocycles, which are being applied to development of new anti-cancer therapeutics. 

 


Last Modified: 11/15/2023
Modified by: Aaron L Odom
